text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Topic TUDomainResourceDefinition Pattern
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, meta, implicitRules, language, text, contained, extension, modifierExtension
url Σ0..1uriLogical canonical URL to reference this Topic (globally unique)
identifier Σ0..*IdentifierBusiness Identifier for Topic
version Σ0..1stringBusiness version of the Topic
title Σ0..1stringName for this Topic (Human friendly)
derivedFromCanonical Σ0..*canonical(Topic)Based on FHIR protocol or definition
derivedFromUri Σ0..*uriBased on external protocol or definition
status ?!Σ1..1codedraft | active | retired | unknown
PublicationStatus (Required)
experimental ?!Σ0..1booleanIf for testing purposes, not real usage
date Σ0..1dateTimeDate status first applied
publisher Σ0..1Reference(Practitioner | PractitionerRole | Organization)The name of the individual or organization that published the Topic
contact Σ0..*ContactDetailContact details for the publisher
description 0..1markdownNatural language description of the Topic
useContext Σ0..*UsageContextContent intends to support these contexts
jurisdiction Σ0..*CodeableConceptIntended jurisdiction for Topic (if applicable)
Jurisdiction (Extensible)
purpose 0..1markdownWhy this Topic is defined
copyright 0..1markdownUse and/or publishing restrictions
approvalDate 0..1dateWhen Topic approved by publisher
lastReviewDate 0..1dateLast review date for the Topic
effectivePeriod Σ0..1PeriodThe effective date range for the Topic
resourceTrigger Σ0..1BackboneElementCriteria for including a resource update in the topic
description Σ0..1stringText representation of the trigger
resourceType Σ0..*codeCandidate types for this topic
ResourceType (Required)
methodCriteria Σ0..*codecreate | update | delete
Interaction Trigger (Required)
queryCriteria Σ0..1BackboneElementQuery based trigger rule
previous Σ0..1stringRule applied to previous resource state
current Σ0..1stringRule applied to current resource state
requireBoth Σ0..1booleanBoth must be true flag
fhirPathCriteria Σ0..1stringFHIRPath based trigger rule
canFilterBy Σ0..*BackboneElementProperties by which a Subscription can further filter a Topic
name Σ0..1stringSearch parameter that serves as filter key
matchType Σ0..*code= | in | not-in | above | below
TopicFilterByMatchType (Required)
documentation Σ0..1markdownDescription of this filter parameter

Documentation for this format

name: Topic
description: Describes a stream of resource state changes identified by trigger criteria and annotated with labels useful to filter projections from this topic.

element.definition: Describes a stream of resource state changes identified by trigger criteria and annotated with labels useful to filter projections from this topic.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $id in f:contained/*/f:id/@value return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Logical canonical URL to reference this Topic (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URL that is used to identify this Topic when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance. This SHALL be a URL, SHOULD be globally unique, and SHOULD be an address at which this Topic is (or will be) published. The URL SHOULD include the major version of the Topic. For more information see [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
element.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid:, but real http: addresses are preferred.  This is the URI that will be used when making canonical references to this resource.
element.requirements: Allows the Topic to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this Topic by the performer and/or other systems.  These identifiers remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: Note: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)).  It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.
element.requirements: Allows identification of the Topic as it is known by various participating systems and in a way that remains consistent across servers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the Topic when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the Topic author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions are orderable.
element.comment: There may be multiple different instances of a Topic that have the same identifier but different versions.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the Topic, for example, "admission".

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Based on FHIR protocol or definition
element.definition: The canonical URL pointing to another FHIR-defined Topic that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Topic.
element.requirements: Topics may be refinements of more generic topics.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Based on external protocol or definition
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally-defined subscription topic or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this definition.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.
element.requirements: Topics may be refinements of more generic subscription topics or definitions.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The current state of the Topic.
element.comment:
A nominal state-transition diagram can be found in the [[definition.html#statemachine | Definition pattern]] documentation

Unknown does not represent "other" - one of the defined statuses must apply.  Unknown is used when the authoring system is not sure what the current status is.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired Topic without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: If for testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A flag to indicate that this Topic is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of Topic that are appropriate for use vs. not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same life-cycle as a production-level Topic would.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use an experimental Topic in production.

element.definition: For draft definitions, indicates the date of initial creation.  For active definitions, represents the date of activation.  For withdrawn definitions, indicates the date of withdrawal.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The name of the individual or organization that published the Topic
element.definition: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the Topic.  May also allow for contact.
element.requirements: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the Topic is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the Topic. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the Topic. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Natural language description of the Topic
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the Topic from the consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the Topic was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the module as conveyed in the text field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Content intends to support these contexts
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These terms may be used to assist with indexing and searching of code system definitions.
element.comment: When multiple usageContexts are specified, there is no expectation for whether all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A jurisdiction in which the Topic is intended to be used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: Explains why this Topic is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the Topic.  Rather it is for traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this Topic.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the Topic and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the Topic.
element.requirements: Consumers of the Topic must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the artifact and/or its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date on which the asset content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The date may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes / editorial corrections.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Last review date for the Topic
element.definition: The date on which the asset content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after that, but doesn't change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this is usually after the approval date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The effective date range for the Topic
element.definition: The period during which the Topic content was or is planned to be effective.
element.comment: The effective period for a Topic  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 would be published in 2015.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Criteria for including a resource update in the topic
element.definition: The criteria for including updates to a nominated resource in the topic.  Thie criteria may be just a human readable description and/or a full FHIR search string or FHIRPath expression.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.definition: The human readable description of what triggers inclusion into this topic -  for example, "Beginning of a clinical encounter".
element.comment: Implementation of particular topics might not use a computable definition and instead base their design on the definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The list of resource types that are candidates for this topic.  For example, the Encounter resource is updated in an 'admission' topic.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Resource types defined as part FHIR.

element.definition: The REST interaction based rules that the server should use to determine when to trigger a notification for this topic.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: FHIR RESTful interaction used for topic trigger.

element.definition: The FHIR query based rules that the server should use to determine when to trigger a notification for this topic.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Rule applied to previous resource state
element.definition: The FHIR query based rules are applied to the previous resource state.
element.comment: The rules are search criteria (without the [base] part). Like Bundle.entry.request.url, it has no leading "/".

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Rule applied to current resource state
element.definition: The FHIR query based rules are applied to the current resource state.
element.comment: The rules are search criteria (without the [base] part). Like Bundle.entry.request.url, it has no leading "/".

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: If set to true, both current and previous criteria must evaluate true to  trigger a notification for this topic.  Otherwise a notification for this topic will be triggered if either one evaluates to true.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The FHIRPath based rules that the server should use to determine when to trigger a notification for this topic.
element.comment: FHIRPath expression with %previous and %current vars.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Properties by which a Subscription can further filter a Topic
element.definition: List of properties by which Subscriptions on the topic can be filtered.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Search parameter that serves as filter key
element.definition: A search parameter (like "patient") which is a label for the filter.
element.comment: Chained parameters are allowed (like "patient.gender") - but can not use colons or modifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Allowable operators to apply when determining matches (Search Modifiers).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Operator to apply to filter label.

element.definition: Description of how this filter parameter is intended to be used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Describes a stream of resource state changes identified by trigger criteria and annotated with labels useful to filter projections from this topic.

element.short: Logical canonical URL to reference this Topic (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URL that is used to identify this Topic when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance. This SHALL be a URL, SHOULD be globally unique, and SHOULD be an address at which this Topic is (or will be) published. The URL SHOULD include the major version of the Topic. For more information see [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
element.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid:, but real http: addresses are preferred.  This is the URI that will be used when making canonical references to this resource.
element.requirements: Allows the Topic to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this Topic by the performer and/or other systems.  These identifiers remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: Note: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)).  It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.
element.requirements: Allows identification of the Topic as it is known by various participating systems and in a way that remains consistent across servers.

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the Topic when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the Topic author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions are orderable.
element.comment: There may be multiple different instances of a Topic that have the same identifier but different versions.

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the Topic, for example, "admission".

element.short: Based on FHIR protocol or definition
element.definition: The canonical URL pointing to another FHIR-defined Topic that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Topic.
element.requirements: Topics may be refinements of more generic topics.

element.short: Based on external protocol or definition
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally-defined subscription topic or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this definition.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.
element.requirements: Topics may be refinements of more generic subscription topics or definitions.

element.definition: The current state of the Topic.
element.comment:
A nominal state-transition diagram can be found in the [[definition.html#statemachine | Definition pattern]] documentation

Unknown does not represent "other" - one of the defined statuses must apply.  Unknown is used when the authoring system is not sure what the current status is.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired Topic without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: If for testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A flag to indicate that this Topic is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of Topic that are appropriate for use vs. not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same life-cycle as a production-level Topic would.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use an experimental Topic in production.

element.definition: For draft definitions, indicates the date of initial creation.  For active definitions, represents the date of activation.  For withdrawn definitions, indicates the date of withdrawal.

element.short: The name of the individual or organization that published the Topic
element.definition: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the Topic.  May also allow for contact.
element.requirements: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the Topic is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the Topic. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the Topic. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.short: Natural language description of the Topic
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the Topic from the consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the Topic was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the module as conveyed in the text field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.short: Content intends to support these contexts
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These terms may be used to assist with indexing and searching of code system definitions.
element.comment: When multiple usageContexts are specified, there is no expectation for whether all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.definition: A jurisdiction in which the Topic is intended to be used.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: Explains why this Topic is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the Topic.  Rather it is for traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this Topic.

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the Topic and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the Topic.
element.requirements: Consumers of the Topic must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the artifact and/or its content.

element.definition: The date on which the asset content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The date may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes / editorial corrections.

element.short: Last review date for the Topic
element.definition: The date on which the asset content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after that, but doesn't change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this is usually after the approval date.

element.short: The effective date range for the Topic
element.definition: The period during which the Topic content was or is planned to be effective.
element.comment: The effective period for a Topic  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 would be published in 2015.

element.short: Criteria for including a resource update in the topic
element.definition: The criteria for including updates to a nominated resource in the topic.  Thie criteria may be just a human readable description and/or a full FHIR search string or FHIRPath expression.
The human readable description of what triggers inclusion into this topic -  for example, "Beginning of a clinical encounter".
element.comment: Implementation of particular topics might not use a computable definition and instead base their design on the definition.

element.definition: The list of resource types that are candidates for this topic.  For example, the Encounter resource is updated in an 'admission' topic.

binding.description: Resource types defined as part FHIR.

element.definition: The REST interaction based rules that the server should use to determine when to trigger a notification for this topic.

binding.description: FHIR RESTful interaction used for topic trigger.

element.definition: The FHIR query based rules that the server should use to determine when to trigger a notification for this topic.

element.short: Rule applied to previous resource state
element.definition: The FHIR query based rules are applied to the previous resource state.
element.comment: The rules are search criteria (without the [base] part). Like Bundle.entry.request.url, it has no leading "/".

element.short: Rule applied to current resource state
element.definition: The FHIR query based rules are applied to the current resource state.
element.comment: The rules are search criteria (without the [base] part). Like Bundle.entry.request.url, it has no leading "/".

element.definition: If set to true, both current and previous criteria must evaluate true to  trigger a notification for this topic.  Otherwise a notification for this topic will be triggered if either one evaluates to true.
The FHIRPath based rules that the server should use to determine when to trigger a notification for this topic.
element.comment: FHIRPath expression with %previous and %current vars.

element.short: Properties by which a Subscription can further filter a Topic
element.definition: List of properties by which Subscriptions on the topic can be filtered.

element.short: Search parameter that serves as filter key
element.definition: A search parameter (like "patient") which is a label for the filter.
element.comment: Chained parameters are allowed (like "patient.gender") - but can not use colons or modifiers.

element.definition: Allowable operators to apply when determining matches (Search Modifiers).

binding.description: Operator to apply to filter label.

element.definition: Description of how this filter parameter is intended to be used.
